hints.content: Start by understanding the constraints of the problem. You need to generate integers of length `n` where the absolute difference between every two consecutive digits is `k`. This means if you have a digit `d`, the next digit can only be `d + k` or `d - k`.
Consider how to generate numbers of length `n`. You can use a recursive approach or iterative method to build numbers digit by digit. Remember, the first digit cannot be zero if `n > 1`.
Think about the range of digits you can use. Digits must be between 0 and 9. If you add or subtract `k` from a digit, ensure that the result remains within this range.
When constructing numbers, start from each possible first digit (1 to 9) and explore valid digits for the following positions. This ensures you avoid leading zeros.
You can use a queue or stack to facilitate breadth-first or depth-first search. For each digit, compute the next possible digits and continue building until you reach the desired length `n`.
Remember to check if the generated number has reached the required length `n` before adding it to your results. If it does, convert the list of digits back to an integer.
Consider edge cases, such as when `k` is 0. In this scenario, all digits must be the same, and you will only generate numbers like 11, 22, ..., 99.
Make sure to handle cases where adding or subtracting `k` leads to invalid digits (like negative digits or digits greater than 9). Use conditions to filter these out.
As you build your numbers, keep track of the unique integers generated. You might use a set to avoid duplicates, especially if `k` is small.
Finally, after generating all possible integers, ensure your result is in the required format (an array of integers) and check that it adheres to the constraints before returning.

questionNotes: No leading zeros are allowed for integers of length greater than 1.
Return the answer in any order.
The integers must be valid (0-9) without leading zeros.
